pr_title: Avoid unhandled out-of-space and OOM on large imports

timeline.message: to avoid OOM, process add/update/dirty.. partially
Verify space to unzip, reduce import mem use

Handle disk full errors on import gracefully

If you run out of disk while importing, the errors percolate up
in the most unexpected ways. This is the actual tested way they show up,
handled in a way that the user sees that they ran out of disk in the dialog
box, so they can hopefully self help

Gracefully handle post-import cleanup failures

The user should get a notice that check database will help
them, but the import actually worked - the data is fine

This can happen if you import a very large deck at the limit
of the space available on your device, because vacuum can take
so much extra space

Gracefully handle post-import cleanup failures

The user should get a notice that check database will help
them, but the import actually worked - the data is fine

This can happen if you import a very large deck at the limit
of the space available on your device, because vacuum can take
so much extra space

timeline.bodyText:
This implies that there is an issue in one of the format strings. Definitely don't suppress here.
EDIT: I tried a PR to turn this into a lint fail, but it didn't fail here.
Looks like an issue with values_ti where someone translated our comment literally:

  
    
      Anki-Android/AnkiDroid/src/main/res/values-ti/01-core.xml
    
    
        Lines 138 to 140
      in
      9595b84
    
    
    
    

        
          
               <string name="time_quantity_seconds">ግዜ_ብዝሒ_ካልኢታት 
        

        
          
           ብዝሒ ግዜ መዐቐኒ ናይ ግዜ እዮም።ብዘይ ምብዛሕን ብዘይ ነጠብን ከኣ ንጥቀመሎም። 
        

        
          
           s,min,h,d, እዚኦም ከም ልሙድ(ISO 31-1) መዐቀኒታት ከምኡ ውን ክትርጎሙ ዘይክእሉ ኢዮም ብውሑዱ ን ቋንቋ ብ ላቲን መስርሕ ቃላት።</string> 
        
    
  


I've fixed the translation
timeline.author: david-allison-1
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -138,6 +141,7 @@ public static long intTime(int scale) {
      * @return The time quantity string. Something like "3 s" or "1.7
      * yr". Only months and year have a number after the decimal.
      */
+    @SuppressLint("StringFormatInvalid")

replies.bodyText: Interesting that we weren't able to get signal from lint on that. Could you open a separate issue about that with what you tried? Should do a full codebase grep on the suppresslint I slapped on there to make sure it's removed everywhere. Then perhaps the linter needs configuration like which resources to load or something (I don't know...) but if Android Studio is able to see it, we should be able to do it on the command line, so it should be possible in Travis...
replies.author: mikehardy

timeline.bodyText:
I've wanted to look into this for a while, as it makes stack traces harder to reason about.
It's the endTransacttion which throws, so I'd presumed that you should be able to get away with mDst.getDb().getDatabase().inTransaction() without the try..catch. Is this not the case?
timeline.author: david-allison-1

replies.bodyText: Nope. Throws anyway. Thus the note.
replies.author: mikehardy

replies.bodyText:
Comment wasn't clear for me (try was ambiguous), could we extract this to a Utils class of some sort, as it'll be needed everywhere.
Alternately, could make a runInTrnasaction method now we have lambdas. But that might be gold-plating
replies.author: david-allison-1

timeline.bodyText:
The point of executeMany is to perform a for loop in a transaction. We've lost the transaction by moving the logic outside.
Have you considered turning this into an iterator, so we can keep the current structure, keep a low memory profile and retain the transaction behaviour
timeline.author: david-allison-1

replies.bodyText: Nope. Was just ferrying 2 year old code from 5 year old bugs into a PR that works for the stated problem. Transaction semantics weren't investigated. I'll look at it a bit maybe executemany can be made aware of existing transactions
replies.author: mikehardy

replies.bodyText: I externalized the txn mgmt in that area
replies.author: mikehardy

timeline.bodyText: Nit: These concatenations inside Timber should be showing lint warnings to use format strings
timeline.author: david-allison-1

replies.bodyText: I used to get those as well. I also remember Timber lint rules showing some sort of internal linter versioning deprecation, and now they don't work - I wonder if Android Studio upgrade broke that? Timber unfortunately non-responsive at the moment though that maintainer is typically thorough 🤔 JakeWharton/timber#391
replies.author: mikehardy

replies.bodyText: Actually, it showed up as lint in the IDE in another area. Some IDE artifact. Anyway, changing them all to formatting now
replies.author: mikehardy

timeline.bodyText: Could you change size for count here. Size (to me) implies a file size.
timeline.author: david-allison-1

replies.bodyText: No, size is not a method on ArrayList.
replies.author: mikehardy

replies.bodyText: I was referring to the variable name, but implementer's choice
replies.author: david-allison-1

replies.bodyText: Ah! Sure. Still in there haven't pushed the NF whitespace commit
replies.author: mikehardy

replies.bodyText: I'll do one nf commit for whitespace and formatting but I wanted to leave the original commit intact as respect for the OP
replies.author: mikehardy

timeline.author: david-allison-1
david-allison-1
david-allison-1

timeline.bodyText: This logic seems duplicated, can we combine it?
timeline.author: david-allison-1

replies.bodyText: No, they increment independently each card can have many revisions, and the revisions might cause OOM before cards would get there, or vice versa.
replies.author: mikehardy

timeline.bodyText: Optional: could we move these two lines next to each other so it's obvious the spacing is for output purposes.
timeline.author: david-allison-1
david-allison-1

timeline.bodyText: Definitely better with string formatting on this one
timeline.author: david-allison-1

timeline.message:
NF: de-lint format strings, fixes were made in crowdin so will persist

Just committing them here to make sure the strings go green, without
doing a full strings sync. All verified on crowdin though, the fixes
are in upstream

timeline.bodyText: Are these d or v? could have 30000 notes in a collection
timeline.author: david-allison-1

replies.bodyText: There were well over that number of notes in the OOM zip I was testing and %d had no problem handling it? I'll investigate
replies.author: mikehardy

replies.bodyText: I see no 'v' possibility for String.format which is used by Timber internally and then delegates to java.util.Formatter https://developer.android.com/reference/java/util/Formatter#conversions which seems as though it can handle any number you throw at it, and matches my testing experience - no problem with this Timber line
replies.author: mikehardy

timeline.author: david-allison-1
david-allison-1

timeline.bodyText:
There may be bugs in determineBytesAvailable: #6442 (could also be my issue).
If so, do we need a way to override?
timeline.author: david-allison-1
